Australian PM urges Pope to sack archbishop convicted of concealing child sex abuse  The Telegraph

Malcolm Turnbull, Australia's Prime Minister, said on Thursday that Pope Francis must sack an archbishop convicted of concealing child sex abuse. Wilson was sentenced to a year's detention earlier this month. He has stepped aside as archbishop of Adelaide in South Australia state, but has not resigned, insisting he would do so only if he is unsuccessful in an appeal. item.title: Bishop gets 12 mts for abuse cover-up (3) - Agenzia Ansa
item.description:
Bishop gets 12 mts for abuse cover-up (3)  Agenzia Ansa

(ANSA) - Rome, July 3 - Adelaide Archbishop Philip Wilson was sentenced Tuesday to twelve months in jail for covering up for a child sex abusing priest. Wilson, 64, was found guilty in May by a court in Newcastle north of Sydney. The archbishop, deputy head of the Australian Bishops Conference, is the highest Christian prelate in the world to be convicted of such crimes. He was found guilty of covering up the sex abuse of four minors by Father James Fletcher in the 1970s. Read the full article on ANSA English

The archbishop of Adelaide, Philip Wilson, will appeal his conviction and sentence for concealing child sexual abuse. Wilson is the most senior Catholic official in the world to be convicted of the crime. He ordered that Wilson be assessed for home detention. Wilson was found guilty in May of failing to report to police the abuse of two altar boys by a paedophile priest, James Fletcher, in the 1970s.
